title: 110_hr3469
content:
The Act titled "America's Border Security Act of 2007" includes provisions for technological assets. The Act "America's Border Security Act of 2007" mandates increased use of Department of Defense equipment like UAVs and radars to aid in surveillance at US borders to prevent illegal immigration. A report detailing current equipment use and associated risks must be submitted to Congress within 6 months. The Act mandates increased use of Department of Defense equipment for border surveillance. A report on current equipment use and risks must be submitted to Congress. Additionally, a pilot program for testing unmanned aerial vehicles along the US-Canada border will be conducted. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct a pilot program to test unmanned aerial vehicles for border surveillance along the US-Canada border. No part of the Army or Air Force can be used as a posse comitatus. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to carry out the program. SEC. 3. INFRASTRUCTURE.

    The Secretary of Homeland Security will construct roads, acquire barriers, and facilities to control US borders. Quarterly progress reports will be submitted to Congress, and appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012.

SEC. 4. PORTS OF ENTRY.

    Additional ports of entry will be constructed along US borders, and existing ports will be improved as needed.

SEC. 5. SECURE COMMUNICATION. SEC. 5. SECURE COMMUNICATION.

The Secretary of Homeland Security will develop a plan to enhance communication using satellite technology for Border Patrol agents and other security agencies. This includes improving communication between agents, stations, residents in remote areas, and other law enforcement agencies.

SEC. 6. UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES. SEC. 6. UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES.

The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to acquire and maintain at least 5 unmanned aerial vehicles and related equipment for patrolling the U.S. international borders. This includes additional sensors, critical spares, satellite command and control, and other necessary operational support equipment. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2008 and 2009 to carry out this mandate. The Secretary of Homeland Security is mandated to develop and implement an aerial surveillance program using unmanned aerial vehicles to enhance border security with Canada and Mexico. The goal is continuous monitoring of each mile of the international borders. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to develop an aerial surveillance program using unmanned aerial vehicles for border security with Canada and Mexico. The program aims to monitor each mile of the international borders, assess surveillance technologies, consult with the Secretary of Defense and the FAA, and address border threats. The aerial surveillance program for border security will consult with the FAA on safety and airspace coordination. It will use various surveillance technologies in different terrains to evaluate effectiveness, cost, and privacy concerns. The Secretary of Homeland Security may continue using aerial surveillance technologies for border security while assessing their effectiveness. Within 180 days of implementing the program, a report must be submitted to Congress detailing the program and any recommendations for improvement. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to establish a program for border surveillance using various technologies to control the international borders of the United States and create a virtual fence to prevent illegal immigration. Appropriations are authorized for this program. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program aims to establish a virtual fence along the US international borders using integrated technologies for automated surveillance. Cameras in the program are required to function automatically, with motion sensor alerts activating corresponding cameras. Camera views and positions are not fixed, and surveillance videos are captured for monitoring purposes. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program utilizes cameras that pan and tilt towards triggered sensors automatically. The cameras do not require manual operation and can be viewed at designated communication centers. A standard process is used to collect intrusion data, and future technology upgrades can be integrated with existing systems. Performance measures are in place to evaluate the program's effectiveness in detecting illegal intrusions along US borders. Plans are developed to enhance response effectiveness. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program aims to streamline site selection, use existing structures for surveillance technology, and deploy mobile platforms for increased border monitoring effectiveness. Plans include developing standards for efficient installation processes and utilizing nonpermanent surveillance platforms to enhance the Secretary's mobility. A report to Congress is required within one year to assess the Program's performance in detecting illegal border intrusions. The Secretary of Homeland Security will submit a report to Congress within one year of implementing the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program, including a description of the program and any recommendations for improvement. Standards will be developed to evaluate contractors providing goods or services for the program. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish standards to assess contractor performance for the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program. The Inspector General will review contracts over $5,000,000 to ensure compliance with cost requirements and program objectives, reporting findings to the Secretary within 30 days. The Inspector General will report review findings to the Secretary of Homeland Security promptly. The Secretary must then submit a report to the Senate and House Committees on Homeland Security within 30 days, detailing the findings and any planned responses. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this subsection. SEC. 8. HIRING AND TRAINING OF BORDER AND TRANSPORTATION SECURITY PERSONNEL. During fiscal year 2008, the Secretary of Homeland Security is required to increase the number of full-time agents and support staff in the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement by 400, and in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by 600. The Secretary is authorized to waive any limitations on personnel numbers to meet these requirements. Ongoing training will be provided to ensure proficiency levels of personnel in utilizing new technologies to protect the borders of the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security must prepare and submit a National Border Security Plan to Congress by January 31 each year. The plan includes a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry on the northern and southern borders, with the option to establish port security coordinators for assistance.
